docs.title: LLM Extractinator
docs.text:
LLM Extractinator is a prototype tool for LLM-based structured extraction. You give it text (CSV/JSON with one text field), tell it what structure you want (Pydantic model), and it will try to produce JSON that matches.

⚠️ Because this relies on LLMs, always verify the output. Models can hallucinate fields or misinterpret text.

docs.title: When to use
docs.text:
• you have many similar reports and want tabular/JSON output
  • you want a no-code way (Studio) to define output models
  • you want a CLI so the same task can run on a server/cron
  • you want to experiment with different local models (Ollama)

docs.title: How to run
docs.text:
1. Install the package and start Ollama
  2. Run Studio with launch-extractinator to design a parser and create a task JSON
  3. Run the same task from the CLI with extractinate --task_id 1 --model_name "phi4"

docs.title: What’s in these docs
docs.text:
• Installation — set up Python + Ollama
  • Preparing Data — what the input should look like
  • Parser — how to design the Pydantic output
  • CLI Usage — all flags
  • Studio — UI walkthrough
  • Manual — for power users

docs.title: CLI Usage
docs.text:
The CLI is called extractinate.

Basic run:

extractinate --task_id 1 --model_name "phi4"

docs.title: Required / common options
docs.text:
• --task_id <int> ID part of the task file. For Task001_products.json, the ID is 1.

  • --task_dir <path> Directory that contains your task JSON files. Defaults to tasks/.

  • --data_dir <path> Directory that contains your input CSV/JSON. Defaults to data/.

  • --output_dir <path> Where to write the extracted results. Defaults to output/.

  • --model_name <name> Name of the Ollama model to use, e.g. "phi4", "llama3", …

  • --run_name <string> Optional label for this run, useful in logs.

Example with all dirs:

extractinate \
  --task_id 1 \
  --task_dir tasks/ \
  --data_dir data/ \
  --output_dir output/ \
  --model_name "phi4" \
  --run_name "baseline"

docs.title: Reasoning models
docs.text:
If you use a model that emits intermediate reasoning (e.g. DeepSeek R1), you can tell the tool to try to extract the final JSON:

extractinate --task_id 1 --model_name "deepseek-r1" --reasoning_model

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
Typical outputs:

  • JSON/CSV with extracted fields
  • logs for each row/document
  • errors if the model could not be parsed into the schema

Always spot-check the output.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Python 3.11 (recommended)
  • A running Ollama instance
  • (Optional) Conda or venv for isolation

docs.title: 1. Create environment
docs.text:
conda create -n llm_extractinator python=3.11
conda activate llm_extractinator

(You can use python -m venv venv instead.)

docs.title: 2. Install the package
docs.text:
pip install llm_extractinator

Or from source:

git clone https://github.com/DIAGNijmegen/llm_extractinator.git
cd llm_extractinator
pip install -e .

docs.title: 3. Make sure Ollama is running
docs.text: Start the Ollama service first; the extractor will call it when you run a task. If Ollama is not running or the model name is wrong, extraction will fail.

docs.title: Next
docs.text:
• go to Preparing Data to see how your CSV/JSON should look
  • or run launch-extractinator to explore the Studio

docs.title: Manual Configuration
docs.text: This page is for users who want to create task files and parsers by hand without the Studio.

docs.title: Directory layout
docs.text:
A common layout is:

.
├── data/
│   └── reports.csv
├── tasks/
│   ├── Task001_reports.json
│   └── parsers/
│       └── report.py
└── output/
  • data/ — your source CSV/JSON
  • tasks/ — your task JSONs
  • tasks/parsers/ — Python files with Pydantic models
  • output/ — where extraction results go

docs.title: Task JSON fields
docs.text:
Minimum viable task:

{
  "Description": "Extract structured info from radiology reports",
  "Data_Path": "data/reports.csv",
  "Input_Field": "text",
  "Parser_Format": "report.py"
}

The only additional field you may want is Example_Path if you intend to use example-based prompting.

docs.title: Naming
docs.text:
Use the TaskXXX_name.json style so the CLI can pick task IDs reliably:

  • Task001_reports.json → --task_id 1
  • Task010_products.json → --task_id 10

Stick to integers in the CLI to avoid confusion.

docs.title: Manual Running
docs.text: Sometimes you want to run extraction outside the Studio and outside the CLI helper — for example, from your own Python script or a notebook.

docs.title: 1. Python entry point
docs.text:
from llm_extractinator import extractinate

extractinate(
    task_id=1,
    model_name="phi4",
    task_dir="tasks/",
    data_dir="data/",
    output_dir="output/",
)

Make sure:

  • the task JSON exists and is named with that ID
  • the parser file referenced in the task exists
  • Ollama is running and the model is available

docs.title: 2. Customizing model / client
docs.text: If the package exposes a lower-level client (e.g. to override temperature or prompt), you can import that instead and pass your own settings. Keep these in your own module so you don’t have to re-edit task files.

docs.title: 3. Scheduling / automation
docs.text:
Because the CLI is just a thin layer, you can call it from cron, Airflow, or any workflow runner. Just make sure the environment has access to:

  • the data folder
  • the tasks folder
  • the Ollama service

docs.title: Parser
docs.text:
The parser defines the output shape: the fields, their types, and nesting. Internally this is a Pydantic model.

You can create it in two ways:

  1. using the visual builder (recommended): build-parser
  2. writing the Pydantic model by hand

docs.title: 1. Visual builder
docs.text:
Run:

build-parser

This opens the UI where you can:

  • add fields (string, int, float, list, nested model)
  • rename the model
  • preview the generated Python
  • export it

When you export, save the file to:

tasks/parsers/<name>.py

docs.title: 2. Structure of the generated file
docs.text:
A generated parser file usually looks like:

from pydantic import BaseModel
from typing import Optional, List

class Report(BaseModel):
    patient_id: str
    findings: Optional[str] = None
    measurements: Optional[List[float]] = None

You can edit this file manually if you want to add validators or docstrings.

docs.title: 3. Using the parser in a task
docs.text:
In your task JSON:

{
  "Parser_Format": "report.py"
}

The extractor will load the Python model from tasks/parsers/report.py and tell the LLM to return JSON that matches it.

docs.title: 4. Good practices
docs.text:
• keep field names lowercase and descriptive
  • prefer Optional[...] for fields that might not be present in the text
  • start with a small model and expand it once the LLM returns consistent data

docs.title: Preparing Data
docs.text:
LLM Extractinator expects that each row (CSV) or item (JSON) contains the text you want to extract from.

The extractor needs to know which field/column to read — you’ll tell it that in the task JSON ("Input_Field": "text").

docs.title: CSV example
docs.text:
id,text
1,"This is the first report..."
2,"This is the second report..."
  • text is the column we will extract from
  • you can have more columns; they will be carried through if the task supports it

docs.title: JSON example
docs.text:
[
  {
    "id": 1,
    "text": "This is the first report..."
  },
  {
    "id": 2,
    "text": "This is the second report..."
  }
]

Again, text is the field we will extract from.

docs.title: Data path
docs.text:
In your task JSON you will refer to the data:

{
  "Data_Path": "reports.csv",
  "Input_Field": "text"
}
  • Data_Path is relative to the data directory you pass to the CLI (--data_dir)
  • Input_Field must match the column/key name exactly

docs.title: Parsers and data
docs.text: Once your data is ready, you must also define a parser (the output structure). See the Parser page for that.

docs.title: LLM Extractinator Studio
docs.text:
The Studio is the interactive way to use this project.

Run:

launch-extractinator

This will start a Streamlit app (usually at http://localhost:8501).

docs.title: What you can do
docs.text:
• Manage data: point to your CSV/JSON
  • Design parsers: same builder as build-parser, but in-app
  • Create tasks: fill in description, data path, input field, parser file
  • Run tasks: trigger extraction from the UI and watch logs

docs.title: Why use the Studio
docs.text:
• you don’t have to remember CLI flags
  • it guides you through the required fields
  • you can try different parsers quickly

After you are happy with a task, you can run it from the CLI on a server.
